body_html:
Mark Schmidt's minFunc is famous for its state of the art implementation of line searches. It's probably a very good reference implementation to benchmark against.

As a side note, the implementation of l-BFGS-b in scipy is a wrapper for the official FORTRAN implementation:

http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.17.0/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.fmin_l_bfgs_b.html
http://users.iems.northwestern.edu/~nocedal/lbfgsb.html

which is probably another good reference implementation to benchmark against.

As a side note, the implementation of l-BFGS-b in scipy is a wrapper for the official FORTRAN implementation:
http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.17.0/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.fmin_l_bfgs_b.html
http://users.iems.northwestern.edu/~nocedal/lbfgsb.html
which is probably another good reference implementation to benchmark against.
body:
Mark Schmidt's [minFunc](https://www.cs.ubc.ca/~schmidtm/Software/minFunc.html) is famous for its state of the art implementation of line searches. It's probably a very good reference implementation to benchmark against.

As a side note, the implementation of l-BFGS-b in scipy is a wrapper for the official FORTRAN implementation:

http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.17.0/reference/generated/scipy.optimize.fmin_l_bfgs_b.html
http://users.iems.northwestern.edu/~nocedal/lbfgsb.html

which is probably another good reference implementation to benchmark against.
